Nile Delta of Egypt: geomorphology,culture and
early agricultural adaptation to climate change
Biography:
Alaa received his Ph.D.degree(1995from the University of Texas at Austin,
USA under a sandwich program between USA and Egypt, His research
interest s fall within sedimentary and environmental Geology,evolution of oil
and gas reservoirs,and evolution of coastal wetlands. Alaa has got several
international experiences from world-class High Education Institutes in USA,
Sweden Germany,UK,China, and Poland. He has published on petrology,
diagenesis and reservoir quality evolution, on the ecological safety measures
from the sediments of coastal lagoons of the Nile Delta,and on the Holocene
Alaa Salem
climate change and its influence on early agriculture from the Nile Delta. Dr.
Salem and his research team are involved in research projects with Chinese
Kafrelsheikh University
colleagues on distribution of inorganic pollutants in lagoons of the Nile Delta

Btja Time
Abstract:
The Nile Delta is a unique geographic setting, being fed by water and
sediment from the African Highlands and the Ethiopian Plateau,and built up by
Venue
the alluvium brought by the old former seven active branches of the Nile and
sea level rise.The topography and geomorphology of the Nile Delta has been
changed much during the last century due to combined effects of:a) severe
coastal erosion processes,b) sediment deficiency since the construction of the
Host
Aswan high Dam, c sea level rise and salt water intrusion, and d human
impacts and extensive land use changes.Holocene climate patterns influenced
the development of early Egyptian agriculture as evidenced from pollen-spore
#iLanguage
data recorded from 2archaeological sites in the eastern and western Nile Delta
revealing a series of wet-dry climate fluctuations. Our results of animal
#XEnglish
dung/hairrevealed that the earliest herding appeared 7.0 ka,BP,which was
shortly followed by farming ca. 6.7 ka BP, as indicated by the abrupt
appearance of cereal (Poaceae >35 um),during a time of climate warming
Results further reveal that human activities actively adapted to climate to meet
shortages of natural resources during climate drying. This was best evidenced
by the abruptly increased abundance of Azolla from ca.4000 years ago,a fern
that favours growing in still-water bodies, suggesting the introduction of
irrigation to the farming system to sustain societal development.

1173: School of Electronic Science and Engineering
GaN-based vertical-cavity surface-emitting laser (VCsEL) has great potential applications in lighting,micro-display
biomedical,underwater detection etc.Electrical-driven GaN-VCSEL was first demonstrated in 2008 in the world.
At present,well-known big companies and scientific research institutions such as Nichia,Panasonic,Sony and
Stanley Electric are engagedin the research and development of such devices,and device properties are
We began study on GaN-based VCSELs since 2006.Through long-term efforts,we obtained electrical-driven blue
violet VCSEL in 2014;For green VCSEL,two solutions were proposed:First,by using quantum dot structure,the
yellow-green light emitting VCSEL in"green gap"was obtained for the first time,and continuous-wave lasing at
room temperature was realized.Second,coupling between the localization state in a blue quantum well and the
resonant mode of the cavity is used to realize continuous-wave lasing of VCSEL in the green at room temperature.
We also obtained the shortest wavelength(276 nm)VCSELin the world,and the first GaN-based red RCLED
This report will mainly introduce the research status of GaN-based VCsEL and our research results.
1166: Math Colloquium No.246
SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
Dynamical Method in CR Geometry
Speaker:Prof.Ilya KossovskiyMasaryk University
Venue: M1001, College of Science Building
Language: English
Abstract
In this talk,I will outline a new "bridge" technique connecting two
fundamental areas of mathematics: Complex Analysis in Several Variables
a part of which is CR geometry) and the theory of Dynamical Systems
Using this bridge technique, a number of significant problems in both
areas have been solved recently. I am going to give an introduction to the
technique and describe some of its application to Complex Analysis and
Dynamical Systems.
About the speaker
Prof.Ilya Kossovskiy obtained his Ph.D degree in the Moscow State
University in 2008 and finished his Habilitation in the University of Vienna
in 2015.He is now Associate Professor of Masaryk University, Brno
Czech Republic.
Prof.Ilya Kossovskiy's research focuses on Complex Analysis anc
Geometry,Dynamical Systems and Geometric Analysis, particularly the
Cauchy-Riemann Geometry,Holomorphic Dynamics and Equivalences ano
Symmetries of Geometric Structures.
Host:Efim Zelmanov
Jointly organized by Math Dept.,NCAMS and SICM

sotopic records of early life,metabolism,and environment on Earth,and the
Alex Session
organic sulfur and carbon cycles. He has published approximately 120
California Institute of Technology
papers,his research group uses the structure,abundance,and stable isotope
composition of organic molecules to solve a range of problems in Earth and
Environmental Sciences,their special expertise lies in finding new ways to
Time
measure the abundance of stable isotopes in these organic molecules,and
applying those new measurement techniques to study a variety of scientific
questions.Alex and John Eiler also started a company called Isotomics to
commercialize the application of clumped-isotope measurements in organic
Venue
molecules.
ZOOM
Abstract:
Hydrogen isotopes in organic molecules are best known for their role as
recorders of terrestrial precipitation and climate,when recorded in plant leaf
waxes.However,work over the past decade on heterotrophic organisms has
revealed a rich and diverse suite of behaviors, that hold potential for
recording many different aspects of metabolism.In this seminarIwillreview
what is known about the controls on H isotopes in lipids,and present some
Host
preliminary data from recent measurements of amino acids.i willargue that
H isotopes are uniquely well suited as a tool for geobiologists interested in
understanding the metabolic activities of microbes,in both modern and
ancient settings.
Language
XEnglish
SUSTech
1170: The driving force of alveolar development
regeneration, and fibrosis
INTRODUCTION
RandalJohnson
2006-201GaiMartin
FA
7II
F2018DevelopmentellEditorialBoard2023SSCR
ABSTRACT
Many organs,and especially the lung, have unique mechanical properties
and are exposed to ever-present mechanical forces. It is therefore
important to carefully consider the coordinated influences of both
mechanical forces and growth factors when investigating the mechanisms
that control tissue development and regeneration in such organs.Here,we
used an integrated combination of mouse genetics, live imaging, lineage
tracing,and quantitative cell biology to demonstrate alveolar development
and regeneration are synergistically controlled by both mechanical forces
and alocalgrowth factor.We have also established a direct mechanisticlink
between impaired alveolar regeneration, mechanical tension, and
progressive lung fibrosis. Our study highlights the essential need to
consider the coordinated influences of both mechanical forces and growth
factors to obtain a comprehensive and thus accurate understanding of the
SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY
development and regeneration of such organs.
1175: SIQSE Invited Talk
Electronic Coherence of Moleculesin Cavities Monitored
by Ultrafast Quantum-Light Spectroscopy
SpeakerZhedongZhang
AffiliationCity University of Hong Kong
Time:2:00pm-3:00pm,Mar.8th,Wednesday
Venue717
Host
Abstract:Quantum states of light,e.g. single photons,entanglement and squeezing,
open a new continent for spectroscopy by utilizing quantum optical fields as novel
control knobs and through the variation of photon statistics.With recent advancements
of optical cavities and quantum technologies, controlling electrons,excitons and
phonons in materials can be achieved,towards unprecedented resolution and
precision. Polariton condensation,as a new class of matter,has been therefore
observed,showing a highly collective and quantum nature emergent from far-from-
equilibrium regime.There are two key issues obscured:electron dynamics within
mesoscopic scale and strong matter-light interaction.The underlying physics is still an
open issue.
In this talk,t will present our recent works on multidimensional spectroscopic probes for
molecular systems interacting with microcavities and quantum states of light.Several
scenarios will be covered:2D coherent probe,Raman spectra with entangled photons,
etc.[1,2].Microscopic models for molecules in optical cavities in the basis of density
matrix and Heisenberg-Langevin approach will be discussed,for a unified
understanding of the spectroscopic signals as well as the molecular polaritons that may
demonstrate a phase transition towards condensation [3]
Bio:Prof.Zhedong Zhang is now an Assistant Professor of Physics at City University of
Hong Kong.He obtained his Ph.D.from the State University of New York at Stony
Brook in 2016.Since then,he has been working as a postdoctoral fellow until 2020
when he moved to Hong Kong.He received the Robert A.Welch Postdoctoral
Fellowship in 2020.Prof.Zhang's research is the theoretical quantum physics,with two
focuses:(1 Nonlinear optical spectroscopy with quantum light for ultrafast processes in
molecules;(2) Mesoscopic quantum thermodynamics for systems driven far from
equilibrium.He has about30 professional publications,on high-profile journals
including Phys.Rev.Lett.,Optica,Light:Sci.&Appls.etc
Refs:[1]Z.D.Zhang.et al.,Phys.Rev.Lett.,in press2023
[2]Z.D.Zhang,et al.,Light:Sci.&Appls.11,2742022)
[3] Z.D.Zhang.et al.,Phys.Rev.B106,L2203062022)

1154: Seeing Protein Dancing in a Longer
1172: SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCEANDTECHNOLOGY
35IdentifyingOldIceandWaterwithSingle-AtomCounting
The long-lived noble-gas isotope 81Kr is the ideal tracer for old water and ice with ages of O.1
-1 million years,a range beyond the reach of 14C.81Kr-dating,a concept pursued over the
past five decades, is now available to the earth science community at large. This is made
possible by the development of the Atom Trap Trace Analysis (ATTA) method, in which
individual atoms of the desired isotope are captured and detected. ATTA possesses superior
selectivityand is thus far used to analyze the environmental radioactive isotopes 81Kr85Kr
and 39Ar. These three isotopes have extremely low isotopic abundances in the range of 10-17
to 10-11, and cover a wide range of ages and applications. In collaboration with earth
scientists,we are dating groundwater and mapping its flow in major aquifers around the world
We are also dating old ice from the deep ice cores of Antarctica, Greenland,and the Tibetan
Plateau. For an update on this worldwide effort,please google"ATTA Primer
R
Zheng-Tian Lu is University Distinguished Professor.Yan Jici Professor of Physics and the Dean
of the School of the Gifted Young,the University of Science and Technology of China (USTC)
He received a B.Sc.from USTC in 1987 and a Ph.D.from UC Berkeley in 1994.Prior to rejoining
USTC in 2015 under the Chinese National Recruitment Program for Global Experts,he was a
Senior Scientist at Argonne National Laboratory and a Professor (part-time) at The University
of Chicago.Throughout his career, Lu has been developing techniques of laser manipulation
and laser spectroscopy of atoms,and applying these techniques to ultrasensitive trace analysis
studying nuclear structure, and testing fundamental symmetries. He received a U.s.
Presidential Early Career Award in 2000,was elected a Fellow of the American Physical Society
in 2006,and received the Society's Francis M.Pipkin Award in 2009
1168: ME
DEPARTMENT OF
MECHANICALAND
ENERGY ENGINEERING
HSAERI
Electromotility: Fast Nanometer-scale Cellular
Deformation as a Non-invasive Biomarker for
Functional Neuroimaging
i#A: Prof. Tong Ling
Bio:
Dr.Tong Ling joined Nanyang Technological University in January 2021
and was subsequently awarded the Singapore NRF Fellowship(Class of
2022).Before that,he was a postdoctoral fellow in the Department of
Ophthalmology and Hansen Experimental Physics Laboratory at Stanford
University.He received his Ph.D.in 2016 and B.Eng.in 2011 from Zhejiang
University.He develops interferometric imaging techniques for a wide
range of applications across multiple fields, including biomedical imaging,
Prof. Tong Ling
optical metrology, and applied physics. He invented the randomly
Nanyang
encoded hybrid grating for versatile quadriwave lateral shearing
Technological
interferometry,which was nominated for 2015 China' s Top 10 Optical
University
Breakthroughs by the Chinese Journal of Lasers.He also received the
Wang Daheng Optics Award by the Chinese Optical Society,the top award
for young researchers in optics and photonics in China.Recently, his
research in full-field interferometric imaging of action potentials
demonstrated a new approach to functional neuroimaging using optical
phase signals,opening the door to all-optical non-fluorescent techniques
for functional imaging in the retina and the brain.
Abstract:
Functionalneuroimaging is a powerful tool for neurodegenerative/neurological disease
diagnosis, and it often relies on detecting macroscopic responses in electric fields or
hemodynamics. In this talk, I will introduce a new aspect of functional imaging at the cellular
scale by tracking the fast nanometer-scale neuronal deformation using high-speed
interferometric imaging techniques.I will describe electromotility,the electromechanical
coupling in the cell membrane, and how it can lead to an all-optical non-invasive
electrophysiology. I will show how this new approach can be demonstrated in vitro to image
propagating action potentials using a common-path interferometric microscope, and in vivo to
map the light-induced electrical responses of photoreceptors using high-speed phase-resolved
optical coherence tomography. These findings provide a new perspective for designing novel
imaging tools for the study, diagnosis, and treatment-monitoring of human retinal diseases, and
may lead to the next-generation all-optical brain-machine interface.
1150: SCIENCELECTURE
College of Science
Researches and Applications of ArtificialIntelligence
in Genomic Computing
#AI
>>>Biography
Dr. Yao Jianhua is the Chief Scientist of Al Healthcare at Tencent Al Lab.His research
interests include computational genomics,medical imaging, precision medicine and
surgical navigation.He is a fellow of American lnstitutes of Medical and Biological
Engineering(AIMBE)and among the Elsevier's list of the top 2% of highly cited scientists
in the world.His papers were cited more than 16,000 times according to Google Scholar
with a h-index of 53.He holds a Ph.D.in Computer Science from the Johns Hopkins
University,USA.
>>>Abstract
Genes determine the inheritance,disease,appearance and aging of living organisms,
and are the most basic elements oflife.ln the past ten years,with the rapid
development of gene sequencing technology,sequencing data has grown exponentially
surpassing Moore's Law.However,the data analysis ability is seriously insufficient,and
the utilization rate of the data is less than 20%.Traditional data analysis methods can no
longer meet the reguirements of modern genomic computing,and new Al algorithms
with the ability to analyze complex big data are urgently needed.This talk will introduce
the research and application of artificial intelligence technology in genomic computing
mainly focusing on several frontier directions such as single-cell multi-omics,spatial
omics and immunomics.The talk will describe the use of Al algorithms to improve the
mining ability of single-cell genomic data, as well as its clinical applications in disease
diagnosis,drug development and immunotherapy
